articles.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

qti_content.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.

One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?"

"Yes, I am," said Aladdin.

The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

"Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

items.prompt: Aladdin's father worked as a

choices.text: baker
choices.feedback: You may have chosen baker because it’s a common job, but look at the lines, “His father worked as a tailor,” and, “Are you the son of the tailor?”—baker is never mentioned. The correct answer is tailor because the text names it twice. Next time, reread for exact clue words and pick the word the text repeats.

choices.text: tailor
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by picking “tailor” as Aladdin’s father’s job. The text supports this when it says, “His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people,” and again when the stranger asks, “Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?” Remember to look for sentences that directly answer the question and repeat key words from the question in the passage.

choices.text: farmer
choices.feedback: You may have guessed “farmer” or mixed it up with another story, but the text clearly says, “His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people,” and the stranger asks, “Are you the son of the tailor?”—so the father was a tailor, not a farmer. The correct answer is tailor because the story states it twice. Next time, reread the sentence that answers the question and underline the exact words from the text before choosing.

choices.text: teacher
choices.feedback: You may have mixed up the job words and chose “teacher,” but the story says his father worked as a tailor, and the stranger asks if Aladdin is the son of the tailor. This shows the correct answer is tailor, not teacher. Next time, reread and match your answer to the exact word the story uses.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.

But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

items.prompt: Which word describes how Aladdin's mother most likely feels about meeting the stranger?

choices.text: bored
choices.feedback: You may have guessed she was bored, but the text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” which does not match “bored.” The right answer is “surprised” because the passage states it directly and explains why. Next time, reread the sentence that tells how the character feels and choose the word that matches it exactly.

choices.text: angry
choices.feedback: You may have guessed she was angry because a stranger came, but the story doesn’t say that. It says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” so the correct answer is surprised, not angry. Next time, reread the sentence with feeling words and pick the word that matches what the text says.

choices.text: excited
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the promise of good money and her welcoming him, which can sound exciting, but the text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” so the correct answer is surprised. To find the right answer, look for the exact sentence that tells how the character feels and match your choice to that word.

choices.text: surprised
choices.feedback: Great job identifying a key detail about the character’s feelings. The text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother.” Next time, look for feeling words and the reason that follows to confirm your answer.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.

The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare.

"Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."

Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

items.prompt: The reader can tell this story is a fantasy because

choices.text: a stranger visits Aladdin's house
choices.feedback: You may have focused on an early detail (the magician visiting), but the text says he “spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… the earth split open,” showing the words caused it. That’s why the correct answer is “words make the earth split open.” Next time, reread the question for cause-and-effect and find the exact sentence that explains what made the event happen.

choices.text: they climb up a steep mountain path
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on an earlier detail (their climb), but the question asks what made the earth split. The text says, “he… spoke magical words… The earth split open right at their feet,” so the correct answer is that the words made the earth split. Next time, reread the sentence where the event happens and pick the detail that explains it.

choices.text: words make the earth split open
choices.feedback: You successfully recognized cause and effect by connecting the magician’s words to what happened next. The text supports this: “he… spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… The earth split open right at their feet.” Remember to look for what happens right before a big change and ask, “What caused that?” when answering similar questions.

choices.text: Aladdin gathers dry sticks for a fire
choices.feedback: You likely focused on a small detail, but the text says, “Then he… spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… The earth split open right at their feet,” showing the words caused it—not Aladdin gathering sticks. The correct answer is “words make the earth split open.” Strategy: Reread the lines around the big event and pick the cause the text points to, not an earlier step.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."

Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help.

"Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.

Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening.

"Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!"

"First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.

The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.

The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.

items.prompt: This story was most likely written to

choices.text: show readers how magic lamps are found
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the detail of Aladdin finding the lamp, but the story isn’t a how-to; it shows what happens because of choices. Look at “He only cared about getting the magic lamp… he spoke a magic spell… Poor Aladdin was trapped”—the magician’s greed causes trouble. So the best answer is that the story teaches that greed can lead to trouble; next time, ask, What lesson do the characters learn from what happens?

choices.text: interest readers in collecting gems
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the shiny gems and thought the author wants to interest readers in collecting them, but the text shows the opposite: “all those gems made his bag very heavy” so Aladdin couldn’t climb out, and the magician “only cared about getting the magic lamp” and trapped him. These details teach that greed leads to trouble, which is the main message. Next time, ask yourself, “Do the events show a benefit or a warning?” and choose the answer that matches the lesson of the whole passage.

choices.text: teach readers that greed can lead to trouble
choices.feedback: Great job—you found the story’s lesson (theme) by noticing how greed leads to problems. The text shows this when “Aladdin…filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy…he could not pull himself out,” and when the magician “only cared about getting the magic lamp” and trapped Aladdin. Next time, look for warnings and then see what trouble follows a character’s choice to want too much to spot the theme.

choices.text: make readers feel sorry for the magician
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the magician’s feelings instead of the main idea, but the text says "The magician grew very angry... He only cared about getting the magic lamp" and even says "Poor Aladdin," so we are not meant to feel sorry for the magician. The story’s lesson is that greed causes trouble: the magician’s greed makes him trap Aladdin, and Aladdin’s heavy bag of gems keeps him stuck. Next time, ask, "What lesson do the events show?" and look for clue words that cover the whole passage, not just one character’s feelings.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him "richer than any king in the world."What does this phrase mean?

choices.text: Aladdin will have more money than he can count
choices.feedback: You successfully made a good prediction by using clues about the magic lamp and treasure. The text supports this when it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the magician promises it “will make you richer than any king in the world.” Remember to look for repeated hints and strong words like “will” to predict what will happen next.

choices.text: Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom
choices.feedback: You may have thought “richer than any king” means Aladdin becomes a king, or you used what you know from other versions, but the text says the lamp “would make any person very rich” and “It will make you richer than any king,” which is about money, not ruling. So the correct answer is that Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: Reread and underline clue words like “rich/richer,” and choose the answer that matches exactly what the passage says—not what you expect from outside the story.

choices.text: Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave
choices.feedback: You may have brought in outside ideas (gold coins), but the text never mentions coins—Aladdin finds “beautiful gems,” and the lamp is said to make a person “very rich,” even “richer than any king.” That means the best prediction is about how much wealth he will have, not a specific kind of money, so “Aladdin will have more money than he can count” fits the text. Next time, stick to the exact words and look for clue phrases about the main idea, like “very rich.”

choices.text: Aladdin will meet kings from other countries
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the word “king” and guessed he’d meet kings, but the text never says Aladdin will meet any kings; it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the treasure “will make you richer than any king in the world.” That evidence points to the correct answer: Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: reread for clue words and choose the option that matches what the passage actually says, not ideas it doesn’t mention.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: What causes the magician to trap Aladdin in the cave?

choices.text: Aladdin doesn't give him the lamp right away.
choices.feedback: You successfully understood cause and effect by noticing that Aladdin doesn’t give the lamp right away. The text supports this when the magician says, “First, hand me the lamp,” and Aladdin replies, “I cannot reach it right now.” Remember to reread what happens right before and after an event to see why it happens.

choices.text: Aladdin won't to go into the cave.
choices.feedback: You may have thought Aladdin refused to go into the cave, but the story says he “agreed to help” and “went down into the dark cave below.” The problem is that “the lamp was buried deep in Aladdin’s heavy bag,” so he couldn’t reach it and didn’t give it to the magician right away—that’s why the correct answer is “Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away.” Next time, reread and find the exact sentence in the text that answers the question.

choices.text: Aladdin takes too many gems from the cave.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the gems, but the text shows the problem happens when Aladdin won’t give the lamp right away: “First, hand me the lamp… The magician grew very angry,” and then he seals the cave. So the correct answer is that Aladdin doesn’t hand over the lamp right away. Next time, reread the sentences just before the trouble to find the real cause.

choices.text: Aladdin breaks the magic ring on his finger.
choices.feedback: You may have brought in an idea that isn’t in this part of the story (the ring breaking), but look at the text: “First, hand me the lamp…,” “I cannot reach it right now,” and “The magician grew very angry,” which shows he’s mad because Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away. The passage never says the ring breaks; it only says the ring will keep him safe. To find the right answer, reread the lines around the event and look for cause-and-effect clue words (like “first,” “when”), and choose the option that matches what the text directly says.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: What is the central message or lesson of this story about Aladdin and the magician?

choices.text: Magic can solve all of your problems if you believe in it.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the word “magic,” but look at how the magician lies about being Aladdin’s uncle, promises riches, and then uses magic to trap Aladdin in the cave—believing in magic doesn’t solve his problems, it creates them. This shows the real lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, check that your answer matches what happens in the whole story, especially the results of the characters’ actions.

choices.text: Be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified the lesson by noticing how a stranger’s big promises led to trouble. The text supports this when the man promises to help Aladdin “learn to become a merchant and earn good money” and says the treasure will make him “richer than any king in the world,” but then he traps Aladdin in the cave. Remember, when finding a story’s lesson, ask yourself, “What happens after a character makes a big promise?”

choices.text: Hard work is the only way to become wealthy and successful.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the detail that Aladdin’s mother works hard, but the story’s events point to a different lesson. Aladdin doesn’t become rich through hard work—the stranger pretends to be his uncle, promises to make him a merchant, then uses magic and traps Aladdin in the cave to get the lamp. This shows the real lesson: be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Strategy: Reread the whole passage and ask, “What warning does the story give?” so your answer matches the main message, not just one detail.

choices.text: Always listen to your mother's advice about strangers.
choices.feedback: You might be thinking about what parents usually say about strangers, but in the story the mother doesn’t give advice—she believes the “uncle,” and he is really a magician. The man promises Aladdin he will “earn good money” and find a treasure “richer than any king,” then he tricks Aladdin and traps him, so the lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, reread and ask, “What lesson fits what actually happens in the whole story?”

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: Why does the magician pretend to be Aladdin’s uncle?

choices.text: So he can help Aladdin become a rich merchant.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the promise to help Aladdin become a merchant, but the story says he was “a powerful magician” who came “to search for a special magic lamp,” and later he says, “First, hand me the lamp.” This shows his real goal was the lamp, not making Aladdin rich. The correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp. Next time, check the character’s actions and repeated clues, not just their first promise.

choices.text: Because he is truly part of Aladdin’s family.
choices.feedback: You may have thought he was truly family because he hugged Aladdin and called him 'nephew,' but the text says, "the stranger was not really Aladdin’s uncle at all" and later, "He only cared about getting the magic lamp." This shows he pretended to be family to get Aladdin to bring him the lamp, which is the correct answer. Next time, reread to find the sentence that tells a character’s real reason, not just their first actions or words.

choices.text: To get Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified a character’s motive by noticing the magician pretended to be Aladdin’s uncle so Aladdin would bring him the lamp. The text supports this when it says he came “to search for a special magic lamp… [and] needed someone to help him,” and later he demands, “First, hand me the lamp.” Remember to ask yourself, “What does the character want?” and look for lines that state goals or demands when answering similar questions.

choices.text: So he can take Aladdin for a long mountain walk.
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on the long walk up the mountain, but the text says the magician came “to search for a special magic lamp,” told Aladdin “Bring that lamp back to me,” and “only cared about getting the magic lamp,” so his goal wasn’t the walk. The correct answer is that he took Aladdin to get him to bring the magic lamp. Next time, look for what the character wants most (the main goal) and make sure your answer matches that, not just one event.

articles.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II

qti_content.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II

Aladdin was stuck in the dark cave. "Uncle!" he called out. "Please help me!" But no one answered. The magician had gone back to North Africa. He only wanted the magic lamp. Since Aladdin would not help him get it, he did not care about Aladdin anymore.

For three whole days, Aladdin stayed in the black cave. First, he yelled for help. Then, he cried. Finally, he put his hands together to pray. When he did this, he rubbed the ring on his finger. The magician had put this ring there. Suddenly, a genie appeared in front of him.

"What do you wish for?" asked the genie of the ring.

Aladdin was scared, but he said, "Take me out of this cave!" In a flash, Aladdin found himself outside again. He ran home fast to tell his mother everything that had happened. He showed her the beautiful gems from the cave. His mother thought they were just pretty stones. Then, he showed her the old lamp.

items.prompt: In the story, Aladdin is like other people in danger because he

choices.text: collected gems from the cave floor
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the gems detail, but the text says, “First, he yelled for help,” then he cried and prayed. It never says he collected gems while trapped—he only shows the gems to his mother after he gets out—so the correct answer is that he yelled for help when he was trapped. Next time, look for order words (first, then, finally) and make sure your answer matches the part of the story the question asks about.

choices.text: rubbed the ring to call a genie
choices.feedback: You may have mixed up the order of events: the text says, “First, he yelled for help… Then, he cried… Finally… he rubbed the ring,” so rubbing the ring happened later and not on purpose to call a genie. The correct answer is that he yelled for help when he was trapped. Next time, look for clue words like “first,” “then,” and “finally,” and reread the question to be sure you’re choosing what happened first.

choices.text: showed his mother the magic lamp
choices.feedback: You may have focused on what Aladdin did after he got home, but the question asks what he did when he was trapped in the cave. The passage says, “First, he yelled for help,” which means the correct answer is that he yelled for help; showing his mother the lamp happens later. Next time, reread for time clues like “when he was trapped” and pick the detail that matches that moment.

choices.text: yelled for help when he was trapped
choices.feedback: You successfully identified a key detail by choosing what Aladdin did when he was trapped. The text supports this: “First, he yelled for help.” Remember to look for sequence words like “first,” “then,” and “finally” to find the exact actions in order.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
"This lamp is so dirty," said Aladdin's mother. "Let me clean it. Then maybe I can sell it to buy us some food." She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp. All at once, a huge genie appeared! This genie was much bigger than the first one.

"What is your wish?" the genie thundered in a loud voice.

Aladdin's mother was so frightened she almost fell down. Aladdin quickly said, "We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!" The genie disappeared and came back with twelve gold plates full of delicious food. Aladdin and his mother ate until they were full. Later, they sold the silver plates and bought more food with the money.

All at once, a huge genie appeared! This genie was much bigger than the first one."What is your wish?" the genie thundered in a loud voice.Aladdin's mother was so frightened she almost fell down. items.prompt: What is the first thing Aladdin's mother does with the lamp?

choices.text: She tries to sell it.
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on her plan instead of her action. The story says, “Let me clean it. Then maybe I can sell it,” and then, “She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp,” so she starts cleaning it, not selling it. Next time, look for what happens right away in the next sentence.

choices.text: She starts cleaning it.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified a key detail by focusing on what Aladdin’s mother actually did with the lamp. The text supports this when it says, “She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp,” showing she starts cleaning it. Remember to look for action words that tell what a character does when answering similar questions.

choices.text: She shows it to Aladdin.
choices.feedback: You may have added something that isn’t in the story, but the text says, “Let me clean it… She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp,” so she doesn’t show it to Aladdin—she starts cleaning it. To find the right answer, match your choice to the exact words in the sentence right before the genie appears. Next time, reread the question and the key sentence to be sure your answer comes from the text.

choices.text: She rubs it with magic.
choices.feedback: You may have used what you know from other stories about magic lamps, but the text says, “Let me clean it,” and “She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp,” showing she is cleaning, not using magic. The correct answer is she starts cleaning it. Next time, stick to what the text says and look for clue words like cloth and clean.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
One day, Aladdin told his mother, "I want to marry the Sultan's daughter." His mother laughed. "Have you lost your mind?" she said. "Your father was just a poor tailor!" But Aladdin said, "Remember those shiny gems from the cave? Take them as a gift to the Sultan."

Aladdin's mother went to see the Sultan. "My lord," she said, "my son Aladdin wants to marry your daughter." The Sultan laughed loudly. "Your son and my daughter? That's silly!" But when Aladdin's mother opened her cloth and showed the gems, the Sultan stopped laughing. He looked closely at the sparkling stones.

"These are amazing!" the Sultan thought. "I have never seen such beautiful gems!" Then the Sultan said, "Your son may marry my daughter, but only if he sends me forty servants. Each servant must carry a bowl full of gems like these."
stimulus.content_text: One day, Aladdin told his mother, "I want to marry the Sultan's daughter." His mother laughed. "Have you lost your mind?" she said. "Your father was just a poor tailor!" But Aladdin said, "Remember those shiny gems from the cave? Take them as a gift to the Sultan."Aladdin's mother went to see the Sultan. "My lord," she said, "my son Aladdin wants to marry your daughter." The Sultan laughed loudly. "Your son and my daughter? That's silly!" But when Aladdin's mother opened her cloth and showed the gems, the Sultan stopped laughing. He looked closely at the sparkling stones."These are amazing!" the Sultan thought. "I have never seen such beautiful gems!" Then the Sultan said, "Your son may marry my daughter, but only if he sends me forty servants. Each servant must carry a bowl full of gems like these."

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
When Aladdin heard this, he rubbed his magic lamp. The genie appeared right away. Aladdin told the genie what the Sultan wanted. Almost instantly, the genie brought forty servants. Each servant carried a large golden bowl. Half the bowls were filled with pearls and diamonds. The other bowls were filled with rubies and emeralds.

The Sultan was amazed by all the treasure. He agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter. Aladdin was so happy! He rubbed the lamp again. The genie appeared and prepared a wedding fit for a prince. The servants brought Aladdin fine clothes and sweet perfumes. They gave him a beautiful horse to ride. They even built him a palace right next to the Sultan's palace. They rolled out a thick red carpet from the Sultan's home to Aladdin's new palace. When the Sultan saw the magnificent palace, he knew Aladdin was perfect for his daughter. They celebrated with a wonderful feast, music, and dancing that lasted all day and all night.

articles.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III

qti_content.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III

Aladdin was very happy with his new life. He thought everything was perfect. But danger was coming. The evil magician heard about Aladdin's good luck.

"That lazy boy?" the magician said. "He married the Sultan's daughter? This must be magic from the lamp!"

The magician traveled back to Persia quickly. He dressed like a poor man who sells things. He carried shiny new lamps in a basket. He walked by Aladdin's palace and shouted, "New lamps for old lamps!"

Aladdin was out hunting animals. His wife, the princess, heard the voice from the street. She thought about the old, ugly lamp they had at home.

"I would like to trade that old lamp for a shiny new one," she thought.
stimulus.content_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III

He walked by Aladdin's palace and shouted, "New lamps for old lamps!"Aladdin was out hunting animals. His wife, the princess, heard the voice from the street. She thought about the old, ugly lamp they had at home."I would like to trade that old lamp for a shiny new one," she thought.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
The princess gave Aladdin's magic lamp to the magician. He gave her a new lamp that was not magic. The magician hurried away with the real lamp. Later that day, he rubbed the lamp. The powerful genie appeared in front of him.

"Take Aladdin's palace and everything inside it," the magician commanded. "Move it to my home in North Africa."

"I hear and I obey," said the genie of the lamp.

The next morning, the Sultan looked out his window. His daughter's palace was completely gone! So was the princess. He was very angry and scared. He sent his soldiers to find Aladdin. They brought Aladdin to the Sultan.

"Find my daughter right now!" the Sultan shouted. "If you cannot bring her back, you will die!"

So was the princess,” which shows the magician used the genie to steal them; the soldiers bringing Aladdin to the Sultan happens after. To get the right answer, think about what big event starts the trouble and choose the option that matches it.

That’s why the correct answer is that the magician uses the genie to steal the palace and princess. Next time, reread the sentences before and after the part you’re using to check the cause (the genie moves it) and the result (the palace is gone).

choices.text: The magician uses the genie to steal the palace and princess.
choices.feedback: Great job! You successfully identified key details by noticing that the magician used the genie to take the palace with the princess inside. So was the princess.” Remember to track who gives orders and what happens next to figure out cause and effect in similar stories.

choices.feedback: You may have focused on a small detail—the princess giving the lamp away—but look at “He rubbed the lamp… ‘Take Aladdin’s palace…’ ‘I hear and I obey,’” and then the palace and princess are gone, which shows the magician used the genie to steal them. Your choice tells what she did, not what happened next. Next time, reread the lines after the trade and pick the answer that matches the big event that follows.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
Poor Aladdin walked far from the city. He felt very sad and worried. He walked beside a river and rubbed his hands together. He did not know what to do. Then he remembered his magic ring! He rubbed it, and the genie of the ring appeared.

"What do you wish?" asked the genie of the ring.

"Please bring my palace and my wife home to me," Aladdin begged.

"I am sorry," said the genie. "I cannot do that. Only the genie of the lamp can move the palace."

"Then please take me to be with my wife," Aladdin said.

Poof! Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa. His wife was so happy to see him! She told him about the man who traded lamps. When Aladdin heard this story, he knew the evil magician had tricked them. He knew the magician used the lamp to steal their palace. Aladdin and his wife made a plan to get the lamp back.

Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa… Aladdin and his wife made a plan.” Remember to look for time-order words (first, then, suddenly, finally) to track what happens next in similar questions.

That shows the passage is telling what happens from start to finish. Next time, ask yourself: Is the author giving steps to follow, or telling a story in order? Look for action words and time order to decide.

choices.feedback: You may have focused on the lost palace and thought the passage gives steps, but it never tells the reader how to find a palace; instead it shows events in order: Aladdin walks, remembers the ring, asks the genie, goes to Africa, learns the trick, and makes a plan. That start-to-finish sequence means the best answer is “telling what happens from start to finish.” Next time, look for clue words like then and suddenly to tell if it’s a story (events in order) or instructions (steps to follow).

Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa… Aladdin and his wife made a plan,” which shows events from start to finish. So the correct answer is “telling what happens from start to finish”; next time, check whether the text gives step-by-step instructions you could follow (how-to) or simply tells what happened first, next, and last (sequence).

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
The next day, the princess cooked a wonderful dinner for the magician. Aladdin hid so the magician could not see him. The princess put poison in the magician's cup. When the magician drank from the cup, he fell down and died.

Aladdin ran into the room and looked for the lamp. He found it hidden in the magician's sleeve. Aladdin rubbed the lamp, and the huge genie appeared.

"What do you wish?" the genie of the lamp asked in a loud voice.

"Take this palace with everything inside it," Aladdin commanded. "Carry it back to Persia and put it next to the Sultan's home."

"I hear and I obey," the genie replied. The palace lifted up into the air and flew away.

The next morning, the Sultan woke up and looked out his window. He was so happy to see his daughter and her palace again! He ordered celebrations for a whole month. From that day on, Aladdin lived peacefully and safely with the princess. When the old Sultan died, Aladdin became the new ruler. He was fair and kind to all people, both rich and poor.

This shows palace means a large building where important people live. Next time, reread the sentence with the word and ask, “Who lives here?” to use context clues.

choices.text: a large building where important people live
choices.feedback: You successfully used context clues to figure out the meaning of the word “palace.” The text supports this when it shows important people living there—“the Sultan looked out his window” at his daughter’s palace—and when the genie moves “this palace with everything inside it… next to the Sultan’s home,” showing it’s a large building for important people. Remember: when you see a tricky word, look at who uses it and what happens around it to infer its meaning.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: In the story of Aladdin, why does the sorcerer disguise himself as a poor lamp seller shouting "New lamps for old"? What is he trying to get?

choices.text: Aladdin's genie lamp by tricking the princess.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by naming what was stolen and how it happened. The text shows this when it says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician. He gave her a new lamp that was not magic,” after he called, “New lamps for old lamps!” Remember to look for the who, what, and how in the same part of the passage and underline those clues to confirm your answer.

choices.text: Goodwill by generously replacing worn-out lamps with new ones.
choices.feedback: You may have thought he was being kind by replacing old lamps, but the story says he was the evil magician in disguise who shouted “New lamps for old lamps!” and then “hurried away with the real lamp,” which shows a trick, not kindness. So the correct answer is that he got Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Next time, reread what the character does after an offer to see if it is helpful or a trick.

choices.text: Permission to work in the palace by offering free replacements.
choices.feedback: You may have thought he was hired to work at the palace, but the story says he “walked by Aladdin’s palace and shouted, ‘New lamps for old lamps!’” and “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician,” so he tricked her into giving him the lamp, not a job. The correct answer is that he got Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Next time, reread the lines about the trade and ask, “What did each person give or get?” to be sure your answer matches the text.

choices.text: Any old lamp that looks valuable so he can resell it for profit.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the cry “New lamps for old lamps!” and thought he wanted any valuable lamp to sell, but the story says, “This must be magic from the lamp!” and shows he dressed up to trick the princess into giving him Aladdin’s special lamp, which he then rubbed to use the genie. So the correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Strategy: Reread for lines that state a character’s goal, not just what they pretend to do.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: What is the central lesson or moral that this story teaches?

choices.text: Magic can solve any problem if you believe in it
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the magic and thought belief could fix everything. But the text shows the problem starts when the princess trades the “old, ugly lamp,” the magician uses it to steal the palace, and even the ring genie says he cannot move it—so believing isn’t enough. The lesson is to be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth. Strategy: Reread and ask, “What choice caused the big problem?” then pick the answer that warns against that mistake.

choices.text: It is better to be poor than to have nice things
choices.feedback: You may have thought the story says rich things are bad, but the text doesn’t say that—Aladdin stays wealthy and later becomes a kind ruler. Look at when the princess trades the “old, ugly” lamp for a shiny one and then the palace disappears; this shows the lesson: be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth. Next time, focus on the main mistake and its consequence to find the story’s lesson.

choices.text: Be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its true worth
choices.feedback: You successfully found the story’s lesson by noticing that the princess gave away something valuable without knowing its worth. The text supports this when it says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician,” and afterward the palace was “completely gone.” Remember, to find the lesson in stories, look at a character’s choice and what happens because of it.

choices.text: Always trust strangers who offer to trade with you because you might get unexpected rewards
choices.feedback: You may have thought the trade led to a good surprise, but the text says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician… [he] moved the palace,” which shows trusting the stranger caused big trouble, not rewards. The lesson is to be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth—the princess didn’t know the “old, ugly” lamp was magic and lost everything. Next time, check what happens after a choice in the story (the result) and choose the answer that matches that main outcome.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: Why was it a mistake for the princess to trade the old lamp for a new one?

choices.text: Because the old lamp was magic, and the magician used it to take their palace away.
choices.feedback: You successfully explained cause and effect by identifying key details. The text shows this when “the princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician… Later that day, he rubbed the lamp… ‘Take Aladdin’s palace…,’ the magician commanded,” and the genie replied, “I hear and I obey.” Remember, when a question asks why, look for what happened and the sentence that caused it—especially commands or clues like because and so.

choices.text: Because the new lamp was shiny but did not help their family and caused trouble in the house.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the shiny new lamp, but the text shows that the trouble came from the old magic lamp: the magician “rubbed the lamp,” the genie appeared, and moved the palace “to my home in North Africa.” The new lamp did nothing; the magician used the old magic lamp to take their palace away. Next time, reread the lines that explain why something happens and make sure your answer matches those details.

choices.text: Because Aladdin wanted to keep every old thing in the palace and told her never to trade anything.
choices.feedback: It looks like you added something the story never says (that Aladdin told her never to trade). The text shows, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician… Later that day, he rubbed the lamp… ‘Take Aladdin’s palace…’,” so the palace was taken because the lamp was magic and the magician used it. Next time, stick to what the story says and underline the sentences that explain why the event happened.

choices.text: Because the Sultan had a rule against trading with strangers in the street, and she broke that rule.
choices.feedback: You may have brought in an idea that isn’t in the story (a Sultan’s rule), but the text never says there was any rule about trading with strangers. Look at “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician… Later that day, he rubbed the lamp… ‘Take Aladdin’s palace…’” which shows the magician used the magic lamp and genie to move the palace away. The correct answer is that the old lamp was magic and he used it to take their palace; next time, reread the lines that explain why the problem happened and pick the answer that matches the text.

articles.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part I

qti_content.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part I

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part I

Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. It had no talking between people either.

"What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice thought to herself.

It was a very hot day. The heat made Alice feel sleepy. She thought about making a chain of flowers from daisies. But she would have to get up and pick the flowers. She wondered if it would be worth all that work. Just then, a White Rabbit ran right past her!
stimulus.content_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
    
    
        Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. It had no talking between people either."What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice thought to herself.It was a very hot day. The heat made Alice feel sleepy. She thought about making a chain of flowers from daisies. But she would have to get up and pick the flowers. She wondered if it would be worth all that work. Just then, a White Rabbit ran right past her!

items.prompt: Based on the story, Alice is probably

choices.text: happy to be working hard
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the idea of making a daisy chain and thought Alice was happy to work, but the text says she was getting very tired of sitting, there was nothing fun to do, and she even wondered if picking flowers was worth all that work. These clues show she was bored and sleepy, not eager to work, so the correct answer is bored with sitting by the river. Next time, reread for feeling words and make sure your choice matches how the character feels in the whole passage.

choices.text: excited about her sister's book
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the mention of her sister’s book and assumed Alice was excited, but the text says she was “very tired” and the book had “no pictures” or “talking,” and she even thinks, “What good is a book without pictures or talking?” These clues show she isn’t excited—she’s bored with sitting by the river, which is the correct answer. Next time, look for feeling words and clue phrases like “tired” and “nothing fun to do” to make sure your choice matches what the story actually says.

choices.text: bored with sitting by the river
choices.feedback: Great job identifying key details about the character’s feelings by recognizing that Alice was bored with sitting by the river. The text supports this: 'Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do.' Remember to look for feeling words and clues in the first sentences to figure out how a character feels in a passage.

choices.text: worried about the White Rabbit
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on the surprising White Rabbit at the end, but the text says, “Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river” and “There was nothing fun to do,” which shows she was bored—not worried. To find the right answer, notice what the passage talks about the most at the beginning and choose “bored with sitting by the river.” Next time, check that your answer matches what the whole passage is about, not just one exciting detail.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
At first, Alice did not think this was strange. She did not even think it was weird when the Rabbit said to itself, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I will be too late!" But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket! Alice jumped up to her feet right away. She ran after the Rabbit and watched him jump down a big rabbit hole.

Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole. She did not think about how she would get back out again. The rabbit hole went down very suddenly. Alice found herself falling down what looked like a very deep well.

The well was very deep, or maybe she was falling very slowly. Either way, she had lots of time to look around her. She looked at the sides of the well as she fell. There were cupboards and bookshelves all along the walls.
stimulus.content_text: At first, Alice did not think this was strange. She did not even think it was weird when the Rabbit said to itself, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I will be too late!" But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket! Alice jumped up to her feet right away. She ran after the Rabbit and watched him jump down a big rabbit hole.Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole. She did not think about how she would get back out again. The rabbit hole went down very suddenly. Alice found herself falling down what looked like a very deep well.The well was very deep, or maybe she was falling very slowly. Either way, she had lots of time to look around her. She looked at the sides of the well as she fell. There were cupboards and bookshelves all along the walls.

items.prompt: How does Alice's situation change from the beginning to the end of the section?

choices.text: Alice goes from running very fast to moving very slowly.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the detail about speed, but look at the text: “Alice jumped up…ran after the Rabbit” and then “Alice found herself falling down…a very deep well,” which shows the real change is from being on the ground to falling, not from fast to slow. The correct answer is that she goes from standing on the ground to falling down a deep well. Next time, reread what changes from one sentence to the next and choose the answer that matches the main change in the scene.

choices.text: Alice goes from following the Rabbit to leading the way.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on who was in front, but the question asks what changes for Alice. The text says she “ran after the Rabbit,” “followed the Rabbit down the hole,” and then “found herself falling down a very deep well,” so she never leads; the real change is from standing on the ground to falling. Next time, reread and look for words that show what happens to the main character (moved, fell, went) to find the change.

choices.text: Alice goes from being curious about the Rabbit to being afraid of it.
choices.feedback: You may have guessed Alice felt afraid, but the text never says that—she “did not think this was strange,” “ran after the Rabbit,” and then “found herself falling down a very deep well.” The real change is from standing on the ground to falling down the well, which matches the correct answer. Next time, reread the beginning and ending to see what changes, and choose the answer that is clearly stated in the passage.

choices.text: Alice goes from standing on the ground to falling down a deep well.
choices.feedback: You successfully sequenced events by identifying key details that show how Alice’s situation changes. The text says, “Alice jumped up to her feet… She ran after the Rabbit… Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole… [and] found herself falling down… a very deep well.” When you answer similar questions, look for time-order clues like “at first,” “then,” and action words that show what happens next.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
"Well!" Alice thought to herself. "After falling like this, I will never be scared of falling down stairs again!"

Down, down, down she fell. Would this fall ever end? "I wonder how many miles I have fallen," Alice said out loud. "I must be getting close to the center of the earth. That would be about four thousand miles down, I think. What if I fall all the way through the earth? How funny it would be to come out where people walk upside down! I will have to ask them what their country is called."

Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.
stimulus.content_text: "Well!" Alice thought to herself. "After falling like this, I will never be scared of falling down stairs again!"Down, down, down she fell. Would this fall ever end? "I wonder how many miles I have fallen," Alice said out loud. "I must be getting close to the center of the earth. That would be about four thousand miles down, I think. What if I fall all the way through the earth? How funny it would be to come out where people walk upside down! I will have to ask them what their country is called."Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.

items.prompt: Read this sentence from the story: "Alice was not hurt at all." In that sentence, hurt means "injured" (physical harm to the body). Which sentence uses hurt with the same meaning?

choices.text: The coach said the loss won't hurt our chances in the playoffs.
choices.feedback: You may have matched “hurt” to mean “cause harm,” but look at the text: “Alice was not hurt at all,” which talks about her body after a fall. “The coach said the loss won’t hurt our chances” uses “hurt” about chances, not a person’s injury, so it doesn’t match. The correct choice is “The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee,” because it uses “hurt” as a physical injury like in the passage. Strategy: Reread the sentence with the word and ask, “Is it about a person being injured or something like chances being harmed?” and pick the one that matches the passage’s meaning.

choices.text: The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by focusing on what happened to the girl after she fell. The text supports this when it says, “Down, down, down she fell… thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves.” Remember to double-check the exact words about what happens next so your answer matches the text closely on future questions.

choices.text: His rude comment hurt his sister's feelings.
choices.feedback: You may have brought in ideas that aren’t in the story, but the text shows only Alice falling—“Down, down, down she fell… Alice was not hurt at all”—and there’s no boy, sister, or rude comment. To find the right answer, pick the choice about a girl falling (The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee) because it’s the only option that matches the passage’s main event; next time, underline key words and match them to the choices.

choices.text: It won't hurt to ask your teacher for help.
choices.feedback: You may have chosen advice that’s not in the story, but look at the text: it only describes the girl falling—“Down, down, down she fell… thump!”—and never mentions a teacher. To find the right answer, pick the one that tells what happened to her (The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee), and next time reread to make sure your choice matches details from the passage.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
In front of her was a long tunnel. The White Rabbit was rushing down it. Alice ran after him. She heard him say, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I am getting!" Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!

Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.

Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.

Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.

Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.

items.prompt: Alice wanted to leave the dark room because she saw a

choices.text: beautiful garden.
choices.feedback: You successfully found a key detail by noticing that Alice saw a beautiful garden through the little door. The text supports this: “Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever.” Remember to reread the part where the character looks or notices something and use the exact words from the sentence to answer “What did they see?” questions.

choices.text: glass table.
choices.feedback: You may have picked a small detail from the room—the glass table—instead of what Alice saw through the little door. The text says, “She looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden,” so the correct answer is beautiful garden. Next time, reread the sentence that answers the question and choose the main idea of that part, not an object mentioned earlier.

choices.text: little bottle.
choices.feedback: You may have picked “little bottle” because it’s mentioned next, but that is not what Alice saw through the tiny door. The text says, “Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever,” so the correct answer is “beautiful garden.” Tip: Reread the part the question asks about and choose the detail that matches that exact spot in the text.

choices.text: golden key.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on a detail (the object Alice found) instead of what the question asked—what she saw through the door. The text says, “On top was a tiny, golden key,” but then, “She looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever,” so the correct answer is beautiful garden, not golden key. Next time, reread the question and find the exact sentence that answers it, then choose words that match that sentence.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: What causes Alice to follow the White Rabbit down the hole?

choices.text: She wants to pick daisies.
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on an earlier detail—Alice thinking about making a daisy chain—but that’s just something she considers. The text says, “Just then… The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket!” which is the surprising event that makes her jump up, so the correct answer is The Rabbit pulls out a watch. Next time, reread the lines with clue words like “just then” or “amazing” to be sure your answer matches the main event the question is asking about.

choices.text: She is bored sitting by the river.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on an earlier detail (Alice being bored by the river), but look at “But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket!”—that sentence tells the surprising event the question is asking about. The correct answer is “The Rabbit pulls out a watch,” because that’s what makes Alice jump up and chase him. Next time, reread the lines around the clue words (like “amazing happened”) and pick the answer that matches that exact moment in the text.

choices.text: The day is very hot.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on a setting detail; the text says “It was a very hot day,” but the question asks what surprising thing happens. Right after, it says “The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket!”—so the correct answer is The Rabbit pulls out a watch. Next time, reread the question and circle words like what happens or what does the character do to pick the event, not the background.

choices.text: The Rabbit pulls out a watch.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by noticing the surprising action the Rabbit takes. The text supports this when it says, “The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket!” Next time, when a question asks what happened, reread that part and look for action words that tell exactly what the character did.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: What is the central message of this story about Alice's adventure?

choices.text: When you're bored, something interesting will eventually happen.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the beginning detail that Alice was bored, but notice the text says she “jumped up,” chased the White Rabbit with a watch, tried the tiny key, and chose to drink the “DRINK ME” bottle—her curiosity drives the adventure, not just waiting. That’s why the central message is that being curious can lead to amazing discoveries. Next time, check that your answer matches what the character does across the whole story, not just one moment at the start.

choices.text: You should always think carefully before making decisions.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the idea of being careful, but notice the text says “She did not think about how she would get back out again,” she “ran after the Rabbit,” and she drank the bottle labeled “DRINK ME,” which shows she isn’t being cautious. These actions lead her to the White Rabbit, the long fall, and the beautiful garden, so the central message is that being curious can lead to amazing discoveries. Next time, check that your answer matches what happens again and again in the story, not just one small part.

choices.text: When you are bored, you should look for something exciting to do.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on Alice being bored at the start, but notice how she runs after the White Rabbit with a watch, follows it down the hole, tries the tiny key, and drinks the bottle labeled “DRINK ME”—these show curiosity, not just looking for excitement. Those curious choices lead her to new places and surprises, so the central message is that being curious can lead to amazing discoveries. Next time, make sure your answer matches what the character does again and again in the whole passage, not just the beginning.

choices.text: Being curious can lead to amazing discoveries.
choices.feedback: Great job—you identified the central message by noticing how Alice’s curiosity leads to new discoveries. The text shows this when “she ran after the Rabbit and…followed the Rabbit down the hole,” which leads her to the tiny door, the beautiful garden, and the “DRINK ME” bottle. Next time, look at what the character chooses to do and what happens because of it to find the message.

choices.text: picking the daisies
choices.feedback: You may have focused on something Alice only thought about, but the text says she just “thought about making a chain of flowers” and never picked the daisies. choices.text: talking to her sister
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the beginning by her sister, but the story never shows Alice talking to her; later, in the room with many doors, “on top was a tiny, golden key… She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked!” The correct answer is finding the golden key, because it let her open the little door toward the garden. Tip: Reread the part the question is asking about and choose a detail from that part, not from earlier in the story.

choices.text: reading her book
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the small beginning detail about the book, but the text says “She looked at her sister’s book once or twice” and “What good is a book without pictures or talking?”, while the big event is “On top was a tiny, golden key… She tried the little golden key… It worked!” The right answer is finding the golden key because it helps Alice open the little door to the garden. Next time, make sure your answer matches the big event of the passage, not just something mentioned at the start.

choices.text: finding the golden key
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by choosing “finding the golden key,” which let Alice open the little door to the garden. The text supports this when it says, “On top was a tiny, golden key… She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked!” Remember to look for sentences that show how the character solves a problem or moves forward, and use those clues to pick the best answer.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: Why did the author write this story about Alice?

choices.text: to explain what a rabbit hole is like
choices.feedback: You may have focused on just one small part—the rabbit hole—but the text doesn’t explain rabbit holes; it shows Alice chasing a talking White Rabbit with a watch, falling 'down, down, down,' finding a 'tiny, golden key,' and drinking from a bottle labeled 'DRINK ME.' Those events show the author’s purpose is to tell about a girl’s unusual adventure. Next time, check that your answer fits what most of the story is about, not just one detail.

choices.text: to tell about a girl's unusual adventure
choices.feedback: You successfully identified the author’s purpose by noticing the story is about Alice’s strange journey. The text shows this with exciting events like “The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket!” and Alice “falling down what looked like a very deep well,” plus the bottle labeled “DRINK ME.” Remember, when you see lots of unusual, make-believe events, think “This is to entertain,” and ask, “What is mostly happening in the story?”

choices.text: to invite readers to go on an exciting adventure
choices.feedback: You may have thought the author was inviting you to join an adventure, but the text never talks to the reader; it just tells what Alice does—“Alice was getting very tired…” and “Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole.” That shows the purpose is to tell about a girl’s unusual adventure, not to invite readers to go on one. Tip: Check if the passage uses “you” to invite or if it tells a story about a character using names like “Alice” and “she.”

choices.text: to show how to follow a white rabbit
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on the detail that Alice follows the White Rabbit, but the passage isn’t giving directions on how to do that; it tells many events—she falls down a deep well, finds locked doors and a tiny door, and drinks a bottle that says “DRINK ME.” These details show the main idea is to tell about a girl’s unusual adventure. Next time, check that your answer fits the whole story, not just one part.

articles.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II

qti_content.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II

Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny.

"What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!

Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.
stimulus.content_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened.

"How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.

Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark.

"Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!

"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.

Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.

Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.

articles.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part III

qti_content.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part III

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part III

Alice kept walking through Wonderland until she found a strange cat sitting on a tree branch. This was the Cheshire Cat, and he had a huge grin on his face. Alice was getting tired of all the odd things in Wonderland. She wanted to find her way home.

"Cheshire Cat," Alice said politely, "can you please tell me which way I should go from here?"

"That depends on where you want to go," said the Cat with his big smile.

"I don't really care where I go," Alice replied.

"Then it doesn't matter which path you take," the Cat said back to her.

"I just want to get somewhere," Alice added quickly.

"Oh, you will definitely get somewhere if you keep walking long enough," said the Cat.
stimulus.content_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part III

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
Alice tried asking another question. "What kind of people live around here?"

The Cat pointed his right paw in one direction. "Over that way lives a Mad Hatter. Over there lives a March Hare. You can visit either one if you want. But they are both completely mad."

"I don't want to visit crazy people," Alice said with worry.

"You can't help that here," said the Cat. "Everyone in this place is mad, including me and you!"

Then something very strange happened. The Cat began to disappear slowly. First his tail vanished, then his body, and finally everything was gone except his grin. The smile stayed floating in the air for a while after the rest of him had disappeared.

"How curious!" Alice thought to herself. "A grin without a cat! I have never seen anything like that before!"

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
Alice continued walking until she came to a house. In front of the house was a large table set up for tea time. The March Hare and the Mad Hatter were sitting at the table having tea. Between them sat a sleepy Dormouse. Even though the table was very big, all three of them were crowded together at just one corner.

"No room! No room!" they shouted when they saw Alice coming toward them.

"There is plenty of room!" Alice said angrily. She sat down in a big chair at the end of the table.

"Have some lemonade," the March Hare offered.

Alice looked around the whole table carefully. "I don't see any lemonade anywhere," she said.

"There isn't any lemonade," the March Hare replied.

"Then it was not very nice of you to offer it to me," Alice said with anger.

"It was not very nice of you to sit down when nobody invited you," the March Hare shot back.

So the best choice is “The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people,” because it also means the piece of furniture; next time, match the word’s meaning by rereading how it’s used in the passage.

choices.text: The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
The Mad Hatter stared at Alice for a long time. Finally, he asked, "Why is a raven like a writing desk?"

"A riddle!" Alice thought excitedly. "This should be fun to solve!"

"I think I can figure that out," she said out loud.

"Do you really think you know the answer?" asked the March Hare.

"Yes, I do," said Alice confidently.

"Then you should say exactly what you mean," the March Hare continued.

"I do say what I mean. At least, I mean what I say. That's the same thing," Alice replied.

"Those are not the same thing at all!" said the Mad Hatter. "You might as well say that 'I see what I eat' means the same thing as 'I eat what I see!'"

The sleepy Dormouse added, "You might as well say that 'I breathe when I sleep' is the same as 'I sleep when I breathe!'"

The Mad Hatter turned back to Alice. "Have you solved the riddle yet?"

"No, I give up," Alice said. "What is the answer?"

"I have no idea," said the Mad Hatter.

"Neither do I," said the March Hare.

Alice thought to herself, "This is the strangest tea party I have ever been to in my whole life!" She listened as the Dormouse told a very odd story about three sisters who lived at the bottom of a well made of syrup. Alice asked many questions because the story was so confusing. Finally, she got frustrated and walked away. "That really was the strangest tea party ever!" Alice concluded to herself as she left.

articles.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part IV

qti_content.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part IV

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part IV

Alice walked deeper into Wonderland and found something amazing. There was a door inside a tree! The door opened to a long hallway. This hallway led to the same beautiful garden she had seen before. When Alice entered the garden, she could not believe her eyes. There were so many people there! She saw royal helpers, royal children, and even the King and Queen of Hearts. They were getting ready to play a game called croquet. The Queen asked Alice if she wanted to play too.

The croquet game was very strange and messy. The ground was bumpy with hills and holes everywhere. But that was not the strangest part. The croquet balls were actually live hedgehogs! The mallets they used to hit the balls were real flamingos. Alice had a hard time holding her flamingo mallet. It kept moving around because it was alive. The hedgehog balls kept walking away from where she wanted to hit them. All the players played at the same time instead of taking turns. The Queen got very angry and kept shouting, "Off with his head!" and "Off with her head!" at everyone.
stimulus.content_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part IV
    
    
        Alice walked deeper into Wonderland and found something amazing. There was a door inside a tree! The door opened to a long hallway. This hallway led to the same beautiful garden she had seen before. When Alice entered the garden, she could not believe her eyes. There were so many people there! She saw royal helpers, royal children, and even the King and Queen of Hearts. They were getting ready to play a game called croquet. The Queen asked Alice if she wanted to play too.The croquet game was very strange and messy. The ground was bumpy with hills and holes everywhere. But that was not the strangest part. The croquet balls were actually live hedgehogs! The mallets they used to hit the balls were real flamingos. Alice had a hard time holding her flamingo mallet. It kept moving around because it was alive. The hedgehog balls kept walking away from where she wanted to hit them. All the players played at the same time instead of taking turns. The Queen got very angry and kept shouting, "Off with his head!" and "Off with her head!" at everyone.

Next time, reread the first lines and look for clue words like “found” to match what the question asks.

Next time, reread the sentence that answers the question and make sure your choice matches that exact detail.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
Alice was lucky to get away from the crazy croquet game. The Queen took her to meet someone called the Mock Turtle. On the way, Alice met a creature called the Gryphon. Alice had never heard of a Mock Turtle or a Gryphon before. She asked what they were, but nobody gave her an answer that made sense. These were just two more strange creatures that lived in Wonderland.

The Mock Turtle and the Gryphon told Alice and the Queen stories about when they went to school. They talked about the subjects they studied. These subjects had funny names like Reeling, Writhing, and Ambition. They also studied ancient and modern Mystery. Alice was sure she had never studied any of these subjects in her real school. The conversation was very odd and confusing.
