choices.feedback: You may have thought Alice was confused because she forgot, but the story says the Mock Turtle and Gryphon learned “Reeling, Writhing, and Ambition,” and Alice “was sure she had never studied any of these,” so the confusion comes from Wonderland’s strange subjects, not her memory. This shows she realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world. Tip: Reread the lines with clues and check if your answer matches what the story actually says.

choices.feedback: You may have thought Alice liked the Wonderland school more, but the text says she had “never studied any of these subjects” and that “the conversation was very odd and confusing,” which shows it felt strange to her, not better. The correct answer is that Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world because the subjects and creatures are unlike anything she knows. Next time, reread for clue words about feelings (like odd, confusing) and make sure your answer matches what the whole passage says, not what you assume.

choices.text: Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world.
choices.feedback: Great job—you successfully found the main idea by noticing that Alice realizes Wonderland is unlike her real world. The text shows this when she meets “strange creatures” like the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon and says she “had never studied any of these subjects in her real school.” Next time, ask yourself, “What is this mostly about?” and underline key details that show differences between settings.

choices.text: Alice wants to learn the new subjects she heard about.
choices.feedback: You may have thought Alice wanted to learn the new subjects, but the text says the subjects had “funny names,” the talk was “very odd and confusing,” and she was “sure she had never studied any of these,” which shows confusion, not interest. These clues—plus the strange creatures and answers that “didn’t make sense”—show that Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world. Next time, reread to find words that show how the character feels and make sure your choice matches what the text actually says.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
Suddenly, someone came running with important news. A trial was starting! Alice ran with the Gryphon to see what was happening. The Knave of Hearts was on trial for stealing some tarts. Just like the croquet game, the trial was a complete mess. The witnesses did not help at all. Then something very strange happened. Alice was called to be a witness too! The Queen said they should announce the punishment before the jury decided if the person was guilty or not. This made Alice very upset.

"Stuff and nonsense!" Alice said loudly. "The idea of having the sentence first!" The Queen's face turned purple with anger. "Hold your tongue!" she yelled. "I won't!" Alice replied bravely. "Off with her head!" screamed the Queen.

"Off with her head!" screamed the Queen.

items.prompt: Read the sentence from Paragraph 2 of this section. "Hold your tongue!" she yelled. What does the phrase "Hold your tongue!" mean in this sentence?

choices.text: be quiet
choices.feedback: You successfully used context clues to figure out the phrase’s meaning by seeing that when the Queen yelled, “Hold your tongue!” and Alice replied, “I won’t!”, it shows the Queen wanted her to be quiet. The Queen’s angry reaction (“The Queen’s face turned purple with anger”) also supports that she was demanding silence. Remember to use what characters say and how they react to decode tricky phrases in future passages.

choices.text: grab it
choices.feedback: You may have read the phrase literally and thought it meant to “grab it,” but notice the talk around it: Alice says, “Stuff and nonsense!” and after “Hold your tongue!” she answers, “I won’t!”—showing the Queen wanted her to stop talking, not grab her tongue. In this scene, “Hold your tongue!” is an expression meaning be quiet. Next time, use the sentences before and after a tricky phrase to see if it’s about speaking or a real action.

choices.text: bite it
choices.feedback: You may have read “Hold your tongue!” as “bite it,” but notice the scene: Alice “said loudly,” the Queen turned “purple with anger,” and Alice replied, “I won’t!”—all showing the Queen wanted her to stop talking. So the phrase means “be quiet,” not to bite her tongue. Tip: When a phrase sounds odd, reread and ask, “What meaning fits what’s happening in the story?”

choices.text: stick it out
choices.feedback: You may have taken “Hold your tongue!” literally and thought it meant “stick it out,” but look at the scene: after Alice speaks loudly, “The Queen’s face turned purple with anger. ‘Hold your tongue!’” This shows the Queen wants Alice to stop talking, so “be quiet” is the correct choice. Next time, use the feelings and actions in the sentence to check if a phrase is an expression, not a literal action.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
Just at that moment, Alice woke up! She was lying on the river bank next to her sister. The sun was still shining brightly and it was a beautiful day. Alice was so excited to tell her sister about her amazing dream and all her adventures in Wonderland. Her sister enjoyed listening to all the wonderful stories.

Alice's eyes sparkled as she told her sister about all the creatures she had met. She talked about the Caterpillar, the Cheshire Cat, the Mad Hatter, the March Hare, the King and Queen of Hearts, and the White Rabbit. When Alice skipped away to have afternoon tea, her sister sat thinking about this magical world full of curious creatures. Alice's sister hoped that Alice would always remember her special dream about Wonderland and keep telling these amazing stories.

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
The Open Road, Part I

"Will you take me to visit Toad?" Mole asked his friend Rat. "I have heard so many things about him."

"Of course I will," said Rat. "Let's get the boat and paddle up there right now. It's always a good time to visit Toad. Early in the morning or late at night, he's always the same friendly fellow. He's always happy to see you, and he's always sad when you have to leave!"

"He must be a very nice animal," said Mole as he climbed into the boat.

"He really is the best of animals," Rat replied. "He is so simple and so friendly. Maybe he's not very smart—we can't all be clever. He might be someone who brags a lot and thinks too highly of himself. But Toady is a great friend."

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
They paddled around a bend in the river. Soon they could see a beautiful, grand old house. It was made of faded red brick. Well-kept green lawns stretched all the way down to the water's edge.

"There's Toad Hall," said Rat. "Do you see that small creek on the left side? That goes to Toad's boathouse. That's where we'll leave our boat. The stables are over there. That big building you're looking at now is the banquet hall—it's very old. Toad has lots of money, you know. This is really one of the nicest houses around here. But we never tell Toad that!"

They paddled up the creek and moved into the shadow of a large boathouse. Inside, they saw many big boats. Some boats hung from wooden beams above them. Other boats were pulled up on ramps. But none of the boats were in the water. The whole place seemed empty and quiet.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
Rat looked around carefully. "I see what's happening," he said. "Boating is old news now. Toad got tired of it and stopped doing it. I wonder what new hobby he likes now. Come on, let's go see him. We'll hear all about it very soon."

They stepped out of their boat and walked across the lawn covered with pretty flowers. They found Toad sitting in a wicker garden chair. He had a large map spread out across his knees.

"Hooray!" Toad cried out, jumping up when he saw them. "This is wonderful!" He shook both of their paws warmly. He didn't even wait for Rat to introduce Mole to him. "How nice of you to come!" he said, dancing around them in circles. "I was just about to send a boat down the river to get you, Ratty. I had orders ready that you must come here right away, no matter what you were doing. You don't know how lucky this is that you showed up right now!"

"What a lovely house you have!" said Mole.

"It's the finest house on the whole river," cried Toad proudly. "Or anywhere else, really," he couldn't help but add.

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
The Open Road, Part II

Toad was very excited when Rat and Mole came to visit him. "You must help me with something very important!" Toad said with a big smile.

"Do you want us to help you with your boat?" asked Rat.

"Oh no! Boating is silly!" said Toad. He made a face like he had tasted something bad. "I don't like boating anymore. It's just a waste of time. I feel sorry that you two still think about boats all the time. I found something much better to do! Come with me to the stable yard. You will see something amazing!"

Toad walked quickly to the stable yard. Rat followed him, but he did not look happy. There in the yard was a brand new travel wagon. It was painted bright yellow and green colors.

"Look at this beautiful wagon!" cried Toad. "This is real life! We can travel on the open road! We can see dusty highways and visit camps, villages, towns, and cities! Today we are here, but tomorrow we can go somewhere else! We can travel to new places and have fun! The whole world is waiting for us! Come look inside. I planned everything myself!"

Mole was very excited. He followed Toad up the steps into the wagon. But Rat stayed outside. He made an angry sound and put his hands in his pockets.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 3
stimulus.content_html:
Inside the wagon were small beds and a table that could fold against the wall. There was a cooking stove, storage boxes, and bookshelves. Toad even had a birdcage with a bird inside. The wagon had pots, pans, and kettles of every size.

"Everything is ready!" said Toad happily. "We have everything we need to start our trip this afternoon."

"Wait a minute," said Rat. "Did you say 'WE' and 'STARTING' and 'THIS AFTERNOON'?"

"Yes! You have to come with me!" begged Toad. "I can't go without you. Please don't argue with me. You can't stay by your old river forever, living in a hole and going boating. I want to show you the world!"

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 4
stimulus.content_html:
"I don't care," said Rat firmly. "I'm not coming, and that's final. I want to stay by my river and live in my hole and go boating like I always do. Mole is going to stay with me too. Right, Mole?"

"Of course I'll stick with you, Rat," said Mole. He was loyal to his friend. "I'll do whatever you say. But it does sound like it might be fun," he added quietly.

Poor Mole! He had never been on a big adventure before. It sounded very exciting and tempting. He really liked the pretty yellow wagon.

Rat could see that Mole wanted to go. Rat didn't like to disappoint people, and he really cared about Mole. Toad was watching both of them carefully.

"Come inside and have some lunch," said Toad. "We can talk about it. We don't have to decide right now. I just want you to have fun. I always try to help others! That's how I live my life."

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 1
stimulus.content_html:
The Open Road, Part III

Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall. The food was always good there. During the meal, Toad talked to Mole about taking a trip. Toad was very good at talking people into things. He told Mole all about the fun they would have on the open road. He made it sound like the best thing in the world. Mole got so excited that he could hardly sit still in his chair. In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. He did not want to disappoint his friends. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure.
stimulus.content_text:
The Open Road, Part III
    
    
        Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall. The food was always good there. During the meal, Toad talked to Mole about taking a trip. Toad was very good at talking people into things. He told Mole all about the fun they would have on the open road. He made it sound like the best thing in the world. Mole got so excited that he could hardly sit still in his chair. In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. He did not want to disappoint his friends. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure.

items.prompt: The passage about Toad Hall is best described as

choices.text: a play
choices.feedback: You may have picked “a play” because the characters talk, but a play shows character names and stage directions before lines. Here, a narrator tells what happens—“Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall” and “He told Mole all about the fun they would have”—so the correct answer is “a story.” Next time, check the format: look for speaker labels or stage directions to see if it’s a play.

choices.text: a poem
choices.feedback: You may have thought it was a poem because of the title, but the passage uses sentences and paragraphs to tell what characters do—“Toad talked to Mole…” and “they loaded up the wagon and set off”—not short lines or stanzas. That means the correct answer is a story, since it narrates events in order with characters (Toad, Mole, Rat). Strategy: Check the text’s structure—poems have line breaks and often rhyme, while stories have paragraphs, characters, and a sequence of events.

choices.text: a story
choices.feedback: You successfully identified the text type by noticing story elements like characters, a setting, and events. The text supports this when it says, “Toad talked to Mole about taking a trip… after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure,” which shows a sequence of actions with characters. Remember to look for who the characters are, where they are, and what happens first, next, and last to tell if a passage is a story.

choices.text: a report
choices.feedback: You may have picked “a report” because it’s about a trip, but look at “Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall,” “He told Mole all about the fun,” “Mole got so excited,” and “they set off on their adventure”—these show characters, feelings, and events happening, not just facts. That means the passage is a story, because it tells what Toad, Mole, and Rat did and how they felt. Strategy: Ask, “Does this tell events with characters and emotions (a story) or give only facts and information (a report)?”

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

stimulus.title: Section 2
stimulus.content_html:
It was a beautiful golden afternoon. The dust from the road smelled rich and good. Birds sang to them from the thick fruit trees on both sides of the road. Other travelers called out "Good day!" to them. Some people stopped to say nice things about their beautiful wagon.

"Ah," said Toad, stretching out his legs. "This is the real life for a gentleman!" They had a pleasant trip along the narrow country roads. Everything was going well until they reached the big highway. That is where disaster struck them.

You road hogs!” and how the car scared the horse and sped away—this shows the drivers were being selfish, so the correct answer is “selfish.” Next time, make sure your answer is a describing word that fits how the characters act, and use the clues the text gives you.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: After lunch, Toad convinced his friends to go on a trip by

choices.text: promising them good food along the way.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the part about the food being good at Toad Hall, but the passage says Toad “told Mole all about the fun they would have,” which is how he convinced them. So the correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have, not promising good food. Next time, reread the sentence that explains how a character convinces someone and pick the answer that matches those words.

choices.text: asking them to help load the wagon.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on what happened after they decided to go, but the text says, “He told Mole all about the fun they would have… In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon,” showing loading the wagon happened later, not what convinced them. The correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have because that’s how Toad talked them into the trip. Next time, reread to find the cause (what changed their minds) and not just the next action.

choices.text: telling them about the fun they would have.
choices.feedback: You successfully identified key details by noticing that Toad convinced them by telling about the fun they’d have. The text supports this: “He told Mole all about the fun they would have on the open road… He made it sound like the best thing in the world.” When you answer similar questions, look for cause-and-effect clues—ask, “What did the character say or do that made this happen?”

choices.text: showing them his beautiful yellow wagon.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the wagon because the text says “some people stopped to say nice things about their beautiful wagon,” but that happens after they already started the trip. In the lunch scene, “He told Mole all about the fun they would have” and Toad “was very good at talking people into things,” so the correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have. Next time, reread the part that matches the question and make sure your answer fits that moment in the story.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: The author most likely included the description of the motor car's appearance to show

choices.text: what kind of damage was done to the yellow wagon.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on one small detail (the crash), but look at the lines that describe the car—“shiny glass,” “beautiful leather seats,” and the loud “TOOT-TOOT”—which show how different it was from their wagon. The wagon “fell over on its side” is just one moment, not the main idea, so the best answer is how different the car was from the friends’ wagon. Tip: Reread the question and pick the answer that matches what most of the sentences talk about, not just one detail.

choices.text: how different the car was from the friends' wagon.
choices.feedback: You successfully found the main idea by noticing how the author contrasts the fast motor car with the friends’ wagon. The text supports this when it says the car had “shiny glass and beautiful leather seats” and sped by with a “big blast of wind,” while the “old grey horse got scared” and their “beautiful yellow wagon fell over on its side.” Remember to look for describing words and compare-and-contrast clues to figure out what the author wants you to notice in similar questions.

choices.text: which parts of the car made the loudest noise.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the loud “TOOT-TOOT,” but the text doesn’t tell which car parts were noisiest; it only says the horn honked loudly, then describes the car’s shiny glass and leather seats and how their wagon flipped into the ditch. This shows the author is highlighting how different the fancy motor car was from the friends’ simple wagon, which is why that answer fits best. Strategy: Check that your answer matches what the whole scene is mostly about, not just one exciting detail.

choices.text: how fast the motor car was traveling on the highway.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on an exciting detail (the speed), but the text only says the car was “coming very fast” and then describes its “shiny glass and beautiful leather seats” and their “beautiful yellow wagon.” This shows the author wants you to notice how different the car was from the friends’ wagon, not how fast it went. Next time, reread the question and pick the idea the text talks about most, not just one exciting detail.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: Read the sentence from the passage. "He did not want to disappoint his friends. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure." What does this sentence show about Rat?

choices.text: Rat cares more about his friends than his own wishes.
choices.feedback: You successfully inferred a character trait by noticing why Rat changed his mind. The text supports this: “In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. He did not want to disappoint his friends.” Next time, look for what a character chooses and the reason given to figure out what they care about.

choices.text: Rat always likes to go on exciting adventures.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the fun parts of the trip and thought Rat loves adventures, but the text says, “In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. He did not want to disappoint his friends,” which shows he went for them, not for himself. The correct idea is that Rat cares more about his friends than his own wishes. Next time, reread the sentence that explains why a character acts to be sure your answer matches the text.

choices.text: Rat is easily excited about new things.
choices.feedback: You may have mixed up who was excited. The text says, “Mole got so excited,” while “Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind… He did not want to disappoint his friends,” showing Rat went along to please them. Next time, reread who is doing the action and match the name; the correct idea is that Rat cares more about his friends than his own wishes.

choices.text: Rat enjoys eating lunch at Toad Hall with his friends.
choices.feedback: It looks like you focused on a small detail—“Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall”—but the question is about what Rat shows about himself. The lines “In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind… He did not want to disappoint his friends” prove he puts friends first, so the correct answer is that Rat cares more about his friends than his own wishes; next time, pick the idea that matches the character’s main action, not just a nice moment.

items.title: Quiz Question
items.prompt: When Toad first sees the motor car with its shiny glass and beautiful leather seats, he most likely feels

choices.text: amazed.
choices.feedback: You successfully made a good inference about Toad’s feelings by noticing the positive details about the car. The text supports this when it describes “shiny glass,” “beautiful leather seats,” and even calls it “the amazing motor car,” which suggests awe. Remember to look for positive or negative describing words to figure out how a character most likely feels in similar questions.

choices.text: ashamed.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the crash and thought Toad felt bad, but the text says they saw “shiny glass” and “beautiful leather seats,” and even calls it “the amazing motor car,” which shows wonder, not shame. The correct answer is amazed because those fancy details and the word amazing signal excitement. Strategy: When a question asks about feelings, underline clue words the author uses (shiny, beautiful, amazing) and match them to a feeling from the text.

choices.text: sad.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the crash and Rat’s anger, which could feel sad, but that happens after the car passes. When Toad first sees it, the text calls it “the amazing motor car” and describes “shiny glass” and “beautiful leather seats,” which are positive clues showing wonder, not sadness. So the best answer is amazed because the words show he is impressed. Strategy: Reread the exact part the question points to and check if the words are positive or negative and whether it’s before or after an event.

choices.text: grateful.
choices.feedback: You may have focused on the nice features and thought Toad felt grateful, but the text says they saw “shiny glass” and “beautiful leather seats” and even calls it “the amazing motor car,” which shows he is amazed, not thankful. Right after, the car causes dust and a crash, and Rat is angry, so grateful doesn’t fit. Next time, look for clue words that name the feeling and check that the events match that feeling.
